content.user_title: Set up Tailwind CSS v4 in Expo
content.value_statement: Setting up Tailwind CSS manually in Expo requires understanding the differences between Tailwind v4, NativeWind v5, and react-native-css. This skill provides complete configuration files and component wrappers for universal styling across iOS, Android, and web.
actual_capabilities: Generate complete Tailwind CSS v4 configuration for Expo projects
Create Metro bundler config with NativeWind v5 transformer
Set up PostCSS config for Tailwind v4 with @tailwindcss/postcss
Provide CSS component wrappers using react-native-css useCssElement hook
Configure platform-specific styling with iOS and Android media queries
Create CSS variable system for semantic colors and theme customization
limitations: Does not execute shell commands or modify files directly
Does not install packages or modify package.json
Requires manual copy-paste of configuration into your project
Does not provide runtime verification or troubleshooting beyond documentation

prompt_templates.title: Basic Tailwind Setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up Tailwind CSS v4 in my Expo app using NativeWind v5. Show me the metro.config.js, postcss.config.mjs, and global.css files I need.
prompt_templates.scenario: Quick setup request with minimal context

prompt_templates.title: Complete Project Configuration
prompt_templates.prompt:
I want to set up Tailwind CSS v4 in my Expo project. Please provide:
1. The metro.config.js with NativeWind v5 configuration
2. The postcss.config.mjs for Tailwind v4
3. The global.css with Tailwind imports and theme variables
4. Example component wrappers using react-native-css
5. Platform-specific styling for iOS and Android

prompt_templates.title: Migration from NativeWind v4
prompt_templates.prompt: I'm migrating from NativeWind v4/Tailwind v3 to NativeWind v5/Tailwind v4. My current setup uses babel.config.js. What do I need to change? Show me the new configuration files and explain what to remove.

prompt_templates.title: Custom Theme with CSS Variables
prompt_templates.prompt:
Set up Tailwind CSS v4 with custom theme variables. I want to:
1. Define custom fonts and colors in CSS
2. Use platformColor() for iOS system colors
3. Create CSS variables that work in JavaScript with the useCSSVariable hook
4. Support both light and dark modes

output_examples.input: Set up Tailwind CSS v4 in Expo with NativeWind v5
Show me CSS component wrappers for react-native-css
output: import { View as RNView, Text as RNText } from "react-native";

best_practices: Use the useCssElement hook from react-native-css to wrap all components that need className support
Set inlineVariables to false in metro config to avoid breaking PlatformColor in CSS variables
Import global.css in your app entry point to ensure Tailwind styles are loaded
anti_patterns: Using babel.config.js for NativeWind v5 - Tailwind v4 uses CSS-first configuration instead
Forgetting to import the global CSS file in your app entry point
Not wrapping components with useCssElement - className props will not work without this

faq.question: Do I need babel.config.js for NativeWind v5?
faq.answer: No. With Tailwind v4 and NativeWind v5, you do not need a babel.config.js for Tailwind. Configuration is now CSS-first using @tailwindcss/postcss and @import directives.

faq.question: What is the difference between NativeWind and react-native-css?
faq.answer: NativeWind v5 uses react-native-css as its runtime. NativeWind provides the Metro transformer, while react-native-css provides the useCssElement hook for component wrapping and CSS variable support.

faq.question: How do I use CSS variables from JavaScript?
faq.answer: Use the useCSSVariable hook. On native platforms it returns the raw CSS variable value, while on web it returns the CSS var() function result for direct style usage.

faq.question: Do I need autopixer with Tailwind v4 in Expo?
faq.answer: No. Expo uses lightningcss instead of postcss-autoprefixer, so you do not need to add autopixer separately.

faq.question: How do I set platform-specific fonts?
faq.answer: Use @media ios and @media android blocks in your global.css to define different --font-sans, --font-mono, and --font-rounded values for each platform.

faq.question: What Lightning CSS version do I need?
faq.answer: Add "lightningcss": "1.30.1" to your package.json resolutions to ensure compatibility with react-native-css.
